summary: A Cover I Love: Iron Man #197 by John Byrne (1985). In art, the simplest approach is sometimes the best one. I have no idea if...
caption:
A Cover I Love: Iron Man #197 by John Byrne (1985).

In art, the simplest approach is sometimes the best one. I have no idea if this was an inventory image or something drawn specifically for the occasion — it certainly has nothing to do with Secret Wars II — but it’s has been one of my favorite representations of “Ol’ Shell Head” since I first saw it on the rack at 7-Eleven.

reblog.comment:

blog.name: queen-of-films
blog.title: Spectacular: The Critic
blog.description: It's all about the movies

body:
Remember the daughters

All of a sudden our beloved heroes are having baby girls. Stark has a daughter. The flash has a future daughter. Ant-Man has a daughter. And don’t forget the Green Arrow. Whenever a superhero has a kid we expect a new journey revolving the newest hero. Sometimes their children are stronger than the heroes for example, legion. I feel like it would be interesting to have a tv show or a movie with the descendants of the most famous heroes. Whether it would be Marvel or DC, otherwise it would be pointless to add children in a hero’s story.

summary: Small minimalistic tribute to one of my all-time favourite characters! RIP Iron Man. Thank you for all the good memories. I love...
caption:
Small minimalistic tribute to one of my all-time favourite characters! RIP Iron Man. Thank you for all the good memories. I love you 3000.

On a side-note, I looked at some pictures of different Iron Man suits for reference and took what I liked best and combined it with what I thought might look good!

reblog.comment:
Small minimalistic tribute to one of my all-time favourite characters! RIP Iron Man. Thank you for all the good memories. I love you 3000.

On a side-note, I looked at some pictures of different Iron Man suits for reference and took what I liked best and combined it with what I thought might look good!

On a side-note, I looked at some pictures of different Iron Man suits for reference and took what I liked best and combined it with what I thought might look good!

blog.name: kuma-style
blog.title: Kuma Style Designs

summary:
A great take on an armor that wasn’t even shown in the movie.
 
Producer: Hot Toys
 Price: Approx. $285 USD
 Release Date: Jan....
body:
A great take on an armor that wasn’t even shown in the movie.

Producer: Hot Toys

Price: Approx. $285 USD

Release Date: Jan. 2014

Item Height: Approx. 12.25″

Item Weight: N/A

Batteries: 3 x LR621 cell, 6x LR521 cell, and 3x AAA batteries

WHERE TO BUY: SideShow Collectibles (Long Sold Out)

The Marvel Studios “Iron Man 3” movie certainly didn’t skimp out on featuring a vast number of suits but one character that was missing was James Rhode’s War Machine armor that was foregone in favor of him using the Iron Patriot armor which was the War Machine Mk II but featuring a red, white, and blue deco (get it?) However, there was concept art done for a more standard colored War Machine Mk II and Hot Toys used it to make a diecast figure of it. Aesthetically it takes a very big departure from the heavily comic-inspired Mk I while still keeping the general vibe of the armor. In this article I show it in motion in the video above, and then give some more thoughts in the breakdown section below as well as a gallery for this piece. Check it out and let me know what you think in the comments.

Presentation: The box on this one is just like the previously reviewed Iron Man Mk XLVI in terms of style and just as impressive. The multi-layered packaging and fantastic artwork is seriously impressive.

Build: The War Machine Mk III from Hot Toys is a mixture of diecast and plastics throughout the frame and it is insanely hefty in terms of both feel and actual weight even compared to the Hot Toys diecast Iron Man pieces I own. The paint and small details like the tampoes and even the offsetting of different silvers on the mark are plain emaculate. The engineering is almost 1:1 with the Iron Man Mk XLVI in terms of things like the waist extending in multiple places and hips dropping down for more range of motion but this one actually improves upon the method and gets further range. It should also be noted that the peg system used for the forearm covers of the light switches are much more well done in the since that they not only peg in and out easier but are less prone to breakage. Even though War Machine hasn’t been portrayed as a main star in the movies, this collectible got just as much attention to detail if not more than any other Hot Toys product I’ve seen.

Accessories: The War Machine Mk. III comes with a good amount of accessories:

– Three (4) pairs of hands:
– One (1) pair of fists
– One (1) pair of opened hands
– One (1) pair of articulated hands
– One (1) saluting right hand.
– One (1) blaster which can be attached to one of five areas on its back.
– One (1) stand with LED features
– One (1) miniature clear War Machine Mk 1 Statue (Sideshow Exclusive)

The accessories are fairly light in number and straight to the point which makes sense considering that this variant of the armor wasn’t used in the movie at all. Everything looks and works fine but I do wish that the blaster was able to actually clip into the attachment points on his back vs. just being held by friction for added security.

Articulation: The articulation points are pretty standard for the Hot Toys diecast armors with a nice amount of range for movement. The amount of forward and back swing that he can get in his abdominal area when extended is particularly impressive.

Overall Score: 7.0/10 – The Iron Man 3 War Machine Mk II is a solid but very bare bones release. I don’t understand the height discrepancy between it and the Mk I and III being so significant and it makes it look even more so like a “b” armor when they’re displayed together. Regardless, it is a fun piece to play with as well as being a nice looking diversion from the very comic-inspired Mark I.

Check out the gallery below, even though the Hot Toys diecast War Machine Mk II is sold out keep an eye on Sideshow Collectibles for all of their latest releases.

Toy Review: Hot Toys Diecast War Machine Mark II (Mk. 2 Iron Man 3 Ver.) A great take on an armor that wasn’t even shown in the movie.

blog.name: ao3feed-tonystark
blog.title: Ao3-Feed: Tony Stark
blog.description: This blog is an automated list of the stories posted on Archive Of Our Own under the Tony Stark tag. The stories are automatically posted here from the AO3 RSS feed.

title: Dark Purposes
body:
read it on the AO3 at http://bit.ly/2QQ5xZU

by egosoffire

Stephen learns how to project magical extensions of his spirit…spiritual tentacles.
Of course, he knows this is a power he can abuse.

Words: 1678, Chapters: 1/1, Language: English

blog.name: littlemsstark3000
blog.title: LittleMsStark3000
blog.description: I love Tony Stark / Iron Man / Natasha Romanoff / Black Widow / IronWidow / IronSpyder Family

summary:
Clint: I think Stark is actually, hopelessly, crazy in love with you.
Natasha: Is that a joke?
Clint: It's an...
body:
Clint: I think Stark is actually, hopelessly, crazy in love with you.

Natasha: Is that a joke?

Clint: It’s an observation.

Natasha: You’re kidding me.

Clint: I’m telling you.

Natasha: Are you nuts?!

Clint: I am Clint.

title: Sapphire Heart
body:
read it on the AO3 at http://bit.ly/2IonWct

by Ikajo

“I worry for him should he remain with us.”

The war between Jotunheim and Asgard never occurred, things were resolved peacefully. A few hundred years later Odin is asked to take in a young Jotun, the son of Jotunheim’s kings. Loki and Thor soon find each other, centuries later they are posed to be married when someone manage to cast them to Midgard.

Words: 1076, Chapters: 1/?, Language: English

  • Fandoms: Marvel Cinematic Universe, The Avengers (Marvel) - All Media Types, Thor (Movies)
  • Rating: Explicit
  • Warnings: No Archive Warnings Apply
  • Categories: M/M
  • Characters: Loki (Marvel), Thor (Marvel), Odin (Marvel), Warriors Three (Marvel), Sif (Marvel), Jane Foster (Marvel), Tony Stark, Steve Rogers, Nick Fury, Natasha Romanov (Marvel), Clint Barton, Phil Coulson, Bruce Banner, Other Marvel Characters
